title: 2010 Dakar Rally (Argentina–Chile)
bio: South America’s second Dakar delivered a classic: Volkswagen swept the cars podium as Carlos Sainz/Lucas Cruz edged Nasser Al‑Attiyah/Timo Gottschalk by just 2m12s after ~9,000 km of brutal dunes and rock-strewn tracks.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Dakar Rally (32nd running)

Date: January 1–16, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Buenos Aires, Argentina (route through Argentina & Chile)

Total Distance: Approximately 9,030 km (cars/trucks), ~4,810 km timed special stages

Participating Teams: 362 vehicles across categories (≈176 bikes/ATVs, 134 cars, 52 trucks)

Returning to South America, the 2010 Dakar mixed towering dunes, Atacama desert stages, and Andean links. Volkswagen’s diesel Touaregs were the benchmark, with Sainz keeping a razor‑thin overall lead to seal victory ahead of team‑mate Al‑Attiyah.

🗺️ Route Details

A trans‑Andean loop from Buenos Aires through Argentina and Chile before finishing back in the capital.

  • Atacama Stages: Fast but navigation‑sensitive dunes and fesh‑fesh around Copiapó and Iquique.
  • Patagonian Links: Long liaisons tested fuel, spares, and fatigue management.
  • Mixed Terrain: Rock fields, riverbeds, and coastal sand demanded versatile setups.

Seven stages in Argentina and seven in Chile balanced high‑speed pistes with technical dune crossings.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner (Cars): Carlos Sainz & Lucas Cruz (Volkswagen Touareg)

2nd Place (Cars): Nasser Al‑Attiyah & Timo Gottschalk (Volkswagen Touareg)

3rd Place (Cars): Mark Miller & Ralph Pitchford (Volkswagen Touareg)

Class winners included Cyril Despres (Bikes), Marcos Patronelli (Quads), and Vladimir Chagin (Trucks), underscoring the rally’s multi‑discipline scope.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Volkswagen Race Touareg: Diesel torque, durability, and stage‑to‑stage consistency delivered the sweep.
  • BMW X3 CC / Hummer H3: Stage‑winning pace but higher attrition and time losses in dunes.

Cooling, filtration, and tire strategy were pivotal across marathon sectors and soft sand.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Waypoints & Dunes: Hidden caps and soft crests punished slight navigation errors.
  • Endurance: Consecutive 400–600 km days demanded strict fatigue and spares control.
  • Mechanical Stress: Corrugations and rock gardens tested suspension and driveline reliability.

Precision navigation and mechanical sympathy were as decisive as outright speed in 2010.

title: 2010 Rallye Automobile Monte‑Carlo (Monaco/France) — IRC
bio: The Monte returned as the IRC season‑opener. Mikko Hirvonen, guesting in a Ford Fiesta S2000, mastered icy tarmac to win ahead of Juho Hänninen and Nicolas Vouilloz.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rallye Automobile Monte‑Carlo (78th running)

Date: January 19–23, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Valence → Monaco

Total Distance: 396.18 km of special stages (asphalt & snow/ice)

Participating Teams: 63 starters, 36 finishers

Classic Monte conditions—night stages, black ice, and tire gambles—favored consistency. Hirvonen’s Fiesta S2000 delivered a landmark win over the factory Škodas after a disciplined tire strategy across the Cols.

🗺️ Route Details

Iconic mountain tests above the Riviera with treacherous microclimates.

  • Ardèche & Drôme: Fast, flowing tarmac with surprise ice patches.
  • Alpine Cols: Mixed grip demanding asymmetric tire choices and precise pacenotes.
  • Harbor Finish: Finale into Monaco under floodlights.

Tyre compound/cut choices swung minutes as weather flipped between loops.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Mikko Hirvonen & Jarmo Lehtinen (Ford Fiesta S2000)

2nd Place: Juho Hänninen & Mikko Markkula (Škoda Fabia S2000)

3rd Place: Nicolas Vouilloz & Benjamin Veillas (Škoda Fabia S2000)

A milestone for the Fiesta S2000 platform, beating the Škoda armada on Monte’s ice‑edged asphalt.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Fiesta S2000: Neutral balance and strong traction on cold asphalt/ice transitions.
  • Škoda Fabia S2000: Factory pace and reliability netted double‑podium points.

Cut slicks vs. studded options defined pace; thermal management was crucial on night loops.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Black Ice: Co‑drivers flagged shadowed zones; precision braking points were critical.
  • Weather Swings: Rapid microclimate changes forced flexible tire calls.
  • Night Stages: Visibility and anti‑cut discipline preserved sidewalls and rims.

Monte rewarded meticulous tire notes and conservative aggression in 2010.

title: 2010 Rally Sweden (Sweden) — WRC Rd.1
bio: WRC’s snowy curtain‑raiser returned after a year away. Mikko Hirvonen charged to victory ahead of Sébastien Loeb and Jari‑Matti Latvala on fast, studded‑tire stages around Karlstad and Hagfors.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rally Sweden

Date: February 11–14, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Total Distance: 1,879.23 km overall (345.15 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 55 starters, 43 finishers

Sub‑zero temps and towering snowbanks favored ice‑racing rhythm. Hirvonen managed studs and pace superbly to seal an opening‑round win over Loeb’s ever‑present threat.

🗺️ Route Details

Classic Värmland tests with a cross‑border Norwegian loop and packed‑snow profiles.

  • Vargåsen & Likenäs: High‑commitment sweepers with snowbank “rails.”
  • Karlstad SSS: Night opener/encore for fans, short but precision‑critical.
  • Hagfors Service: Strategy hub for stud preservation and setup tweaks.

Second passes polished to ice; early road positions enjoyed cleaner bite.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Mikko Hirvonen & Jarmo Lehtinen (Ford Focus RS WRC 09)

2nd Place: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

3rd Place: Jari‑Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Focus RS WRC 09)

A confident, measured run by Hirvonen—controlling pace and minimizing stud loss—set the tone for Ford’s campaign.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Stability on icy transitions and strong traction on compacted snow.
  • Citroën C4 WRC: Precise turn‑in helped Loeb carve time on technical sections.

Stud selection and temperature management were decisive performance variables.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Bank Usage: Controlled brush to stabilize cornering without getting sucked in.
  • Grip Evolution: Notes updated for polished ice on second passes.
  • Cold Reliability: Warm‑up cycles to protect hydraulics and transmissions.

Precision pacenotes and smooth inputs paid dividends on Sweden’s fast ice ribbons.

title: 2010 Rally México (Mexico) — WRC Rd.2
bio: León’s high‑altitude gravel punished engines and brakes. Sébastien Loeb seized control on Saturday to win from Petter Solberg, with Sébastien Ogier narrowly third.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rally México (Rally Guanajuato Bicentenario)

Date: March 5–7, 2010

Start/Finish Location: León, Guanajuato

Total Distance: 877.53 km overall (354.60 km of special stages; 7.05 km cancelled)

Participating Teams: 30 starters, 25 finishers

Thin air cut power and stressed cooling. After Solberg’s early charge, Loeb strung together stage wins on Saturday to build an unassailable gap and open his 2010 victory account.

🗺️ Route Details

Mountain gravel above León mixed long climbs with rocky descents and arena‑style superspecials.

  • Ibarrilla/Duarte/Derramadero: Altitude compression and brake fade management crucial.
  • Autódromo Super Specials: Spectator‑friendly, low‑risk time traps.
  • Surface Wear: Second‑pass ruts and stones raised puncture risk.

ECU mapping and cooling strategies countered the ~2,700 m elevation in key sections.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

2nd Place: Petter Solberg & Phil Mills (Citroën C4 WRC)

3rd Place: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën C4 WRC)

Loeb overturned Solberg’s leg‑one lead and edged Ogier in a Citroën‑lockout podium.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën C4 WRC: Cooling robustness and traction over rutted gravel paid off at altitude.
  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Solid pace, but cumulative seconds slipped in rough second passes.

Filtration, brake cooling, and puncture prevention defined service priorities.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Altitude Effects: Pacenotes flagged thin‑air braking points and power‑limited climbs.
  • Ruts & Rocks: Line choice and caution notes minimized rim and tire damage.
  • Liaison Heat: Hydration/logistics mattered on long midday road sections.

Mexico rewarded mechanical sympathy and steady Sunday risk management.

title: 2010 Jordan Rally (Jordan) — WRC Rd.3
bio: Set along the Dead Sea, the Jordan Rally challenged crews with below-sea-level heat, hard-packed gravel, and twisty desert tracks. Sébastien Loeb edged Jari-Matti Latvala in a nail-biting finish.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Jordan Rally

Date: April 1–3, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Dead Sea, Jordan

Total Distance: 983.44 km overall (339.48 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 32 starters, 28 finishers

The WRC’s lowest-altitude event ran on compact desert gravel, where minimal grip and punishing rock edges tested patience. Loeb snatched victory by just 35.8 seconds after a close fight with Latvala through the final day’s stages.

🗺️ Route Details

Stages were tightly grouped around the Dead Sea service park, offering a mix of smooth, fast stretches and slow, technical corners.

  • Jordan Valley: High-speed sections broken by tight hairpins and rock outcrops.
  • Desert Plains: Long straights exposed to windblown dust reducing visibility.
  • Heat Factor: Midday stage temps exceeded 30°C, affecting both crews and cars.

Hard-packed gravel offered grip early but degraded into loose marbles on second passes.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

2nd Place: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Focus RS WRC 09)

3rd Place: Petter Solberg & Phil Mills (Citroën C4 WRC)

Loeb’s win was secured through consistent pace and flawless tire preservation under scorching conditions.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën C4 WRC: Stability in fast sweepers and reliability in extreme heat made it the car to beat.
  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Quick in technical sections, Latvala kept pressure until the final loop.

Dust sealing, cooling systems, and suspension toughness were critical to finishing strongly.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Dust Clouds: Reduced visibility demanded precise distance calls from co-drivers.
  • Rock Strikes: Pacenotes flagged high-risk edges to avoid punctures.
  • Heat Stress: Crew hydration and cockpit cooling strategies were essential.

Jordan rewarded patience, clean lines, and meticulous tire management in oppressive heat.

title: 2010 Rally of Turkey (Turkey) — WRC Rd.4
bio: A return to gravel for the Rally of Turkey brought rough mountain tracks, loose gravel, and mixed asphalt sections. Sébastien Loeb survived a dramatic final day to take his third win of the season.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rally of Turkey

Date: April 16–18, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Istanbul, Turkey

Total Distance: 1,174.16 km overall (358.84 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 38 starters, 33 finishers

The Turkish stages combined rocky mountain gravel with stretches of asphalt, demanding adaptable driving. Loeb held off Hirvonen and Ogier in a tense final leg, consolidating his championship lead.

🗺️ Route Details

Rally HQ in Istanbul’s Pendik district provided quick access to diverse stage profiles.

  • Mountain Gravel: Loose, rocky climbs and descents punished suspension and tires.
  • Asphalt Links: Abrupt surface changes tested grip adaptability.
  • Urban Super Specials: Tight, barrier-lined stages for spectators.

Variable weather created occasional damp patches, adding unpredictability to grip levels.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

2nd Place: Mikko Hirvonen & Jarmo Lehtinen (Ford Focus RS WRC 09)

3rd Place: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën C4 WRC)

Ogier’s pace was a highlight, while Loeb’s tire choice and consistency proved decisive.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën C4 WRC: Balanced on mixed surfaces, providing confidence under braking and acceleration.
  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Durable under rougher conditions but slightly slower on asphalt transitions.

Cars needed suspension setups that could handle impacts without sacrificing grip on tarmac.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Surface Changes: Co-drivers warned of grip shifts between gravel and asphalt.
  • Rock Hazards: Careful line selection to avoid punctures and suspension damage.
  • Fast Blind Crests: Precise pacenote timing was critical for safe landings.

Adaptability and mechanical preservation were key to mastering the 2010 Turkish terrain.

title: 2010 Rally New Zealand (New Zealand) — WRC Rd.5
bio: Smooth cambered gravel and coastal winds set the scene for a dramatic finale in New Zealand. Jari-Matti Latvala capitalized on Loeb’s error to take his first win of the season.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rally New Zealand

Date: May 7–9, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Auckland, New Zealand

Total Distance: 1,344.38 km overall (396.50 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 40 starters, 34 finishers

Fast, flowing gravel roads and stunning scenery made Rally NZ a driver favorite. Latvala drove flawlessly while Loeb’s rare off-road excursion cost him valuable time, handing Ford their first win of the season.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally featured classic North Island stages known for their smoothness and camber.

  • Whangarei & Kaipara: High-speed sweepers and flowing rhythm.
  • Cambered Corners: Allowed drivers to carry more speed with less sliding.
  • Coastal Winds: Gusts could unsettle cars on open sections.

Minimal loose gravel on the racing line kept grip levels high for early runners.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Focus RS WRC 09)

2nd Place: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën C4 WRC)

3rd Place: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

Latvala’s controlled pace and Loeb’s rare slip-up defined the rally’s outcome.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Suited to the flowing, cambered roads, giving Latvala a confidence edge.
  • Citroën C4 WRC: Maintained strong speed but Loeb’s off offset its advantage.

Stable suspension geometry and predictable cornering balance were key to success.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • High-Speed Rhythm: Required precise pacenote delivery to maintain flow.
  • Wind Gusts: Sudden crosswinds near the coast needed quick corrections.
  • Grip Consistency: Minimal surface changes allowed confident pace but punished over-driving.

Patience and precise corner placement rewarded drivers in New Zealand’s smooth gravel paradise.

title: 2010 Rally de Portugal (Portugal) — WRC Rd.6
bio: Based in the Algarve, Rally de Portugal’s mix of smooth and rough gravel tested tire endurance and heat management. Sébastien Ogier scored his first WRC win after a tight battle with Loeb and Hirvonen.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rally de Portugal

Date: May 27–30, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Faro, Algarve

Total Distance: 1,020.49 km overall (355.32 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 43 starters, 36 finishers

Ogier delivered a breakthrough performance, maintaining composure under pressure to secure his first WRC victory. Loeb and Hirvonen were close throughout, but Ogier’s pace on Sunday sealed the deal.

🗺️ Route Details

Stages wound through southern Portugal’s gravel hills, offering varied speeds and surface quality.

  • Almodôvar & Santa Clara: Fast and flowing with some rocky sections.
  • Silves & Loule: Technical, twisty stretches with blind crests.
  • Lisbon Super Special: Tarmac showcase for spectators in the capital.

High temperatures and abrasive gravel made tire wear a strategic concern.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën C4 WRC)

2nd Place: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

3rd Place: Mikko Hirvonen & Jarmo Lehtinen (Ford Focus RS WRC 09)

Ogier’s consistent pace under pressure marked him as a rising WRC star.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën C4 WRC: Excellent balance on both fast and technical gravel.
  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Strong durability but slightly less agile in twisty sections.

Setup aimed to minimize tire degradation while retaining grip in long stages.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Tire Management: Co-drivers advised lift points to preserve rubber.
  • Dust Trails: Visibility was a factor on windy ridges.
  • Blind Crests: Accurate pacenotes essential to maintain speed safely.

Portugal rewarded those who could push hard while protecting their tires from the Algarve’s abrasive gravel.

title: 2010 Rally Bulgaria (Bulgaria) — WRC Rd.7
bio: Bulgaria’s WRC debut brought pristine asphalt stages in the Rila Mountains. Sébastien Loeb dominated from start to finish, with Dani Sordo securing second for a Citroën 1–2.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rally Bulgaria

Date: July 9–11, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Borovets, Bulgaria

Total Distance: 1,010.65 km overall (354.10 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 60 starters, 49 finishers

Smooth, high-speed tarmac roads and scenic mountain backdrops defined Bulgaria’s WRC debut. Loeb controlled the pace throughout, with Sordo playing perfect team support to secure maximum points for Citroën.

🗺️ Route Details

All-asphalt route through the Rila Mountains with long, sweeping corners.

  • Mountain Stages: Constant radius corners allowing high average speeds.
  • Wide Roads: Encouraged aggressive cornering and late braking.
  • Elevation Changes: Minor altitude variation but mostly consistent grip.

The new event was praised for smooth surfaces and excellent organization.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

2nd Place: Dani Sordo & Marc Martí (Citroën C4 WRC)

3rd Place: Petter Solberg & Phil Mills (Citroën C4 WRC)

Citroën swept the podium places in a dominant asphalt display.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën C4 WRC: Unmatched on asphalt, delivering both speed and precision.
  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Quick but struggled to match Citroën’s pace in long sweepers.

Asphalt setup emphasized sharp turn-in and maximum braking stability.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • High-Speed Corners: Co-drivers kept rhythm to sustain momentum.
  • Cut Options: Judged carefully to avoid dragging gravel onto the road.
  • Temperature Management: Warm summer weather required careful tire temperature control.

Bulgaria rewarded clean, flowing driving lines and disciplined tire preservation.

title: 2010 Rally Finland (Finland) — WRC Rd.8
bio: The fastest rally of the year saw Jari-Matti Latvala thrill home fans with a near-win, but Sébastien Loeb’s clinical precision secured his third Finland victory.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rally Finland (Neste Oil Rally Finland)

Date: July 29–31, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Total Distance: 1,009.25 km overall (310.05 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 88 starters, 55 finishers

Flat-out gravel roads, massive jumps, and flowing crests kept average speeds high. Latvala pushed Loeb all the way, but the Frenchman’s calm, mistake-free drive secured another iconic Finland win.

🗺️ Route Details

Finland’s stages are renowned for their high speeds and airborne moments.

  • Ouninpohja-style Jumps: Demanded perfect commitment and pacenote accuracy.
  • Fast Gravel: Firm, smooth base allowed for maximum attack.
  • Short Rally Format: Two-day competition increased intensity.

Road position played a smaller role thanks to minimal loose gravel buildup.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

2nd Place: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Focus RS WRC 09)

3rd Place: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën C4 WRC)

Latvala thrilled local fans but Loeb’s consistency and precise pacenotes were unbeatable.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën C4 WRC: Balanced perfectly for high-speed stability and corner entry confidence.
  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Excellent on jumps and heavy landings, slightly less precise in hairpins.

Gravel suspension tuning prioritized stability on crests and fast compressions.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Jump Calls: Perfect timing critical to avoid unsettling the car mid-air.
  • Blind Crests: Required absolute trust between driver and co-driver.
  • Corner Linking: Finland’s rhythm depends on anticipating sequences, not isolated corners.

Finland rewarded bravery backed by immaculate pacenote delivery and car control.

title: 2010 Rallye Deutschland (Germany) — WRC Rd.9
bio: Returning after a year off the calendar, Rallye Deutschland once again delivered tight vineyard roads, military asphalt, and unpredictable weather. Sébastien Loeb took his eighth straight win on home soil.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rallye Deutschland

Date: August 20–22, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Trier, Germany

Total Distance: 1,186.36 km overall (407.31 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 85 starters, 63 finishers

Germany’s combination of twisty vineyard lanes, rough military asphalt, and sudden showers kept crews on edge. Loeb was untouchable once again, extending his perfect record at the event to eight wins in a row.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally mixed narrow, bumpy tarmac with wide, high-speed military roads.

  • Mosel Vineyards: Tight hairpins and narrow access roads lined with vines and stone walls.
  • Baumholder: Concrete tank tracks with unpredictable grip and hinkelsteins (large concrete blocks).
  • Saarland Roads: Faster, smoother asphalt with elevation changes.

Weather variations between stages often forced last-minute tire decisions.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

2nd Place: Dani Sordo & Marc Martí (Citroën C4 WRC)

3rd Place: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën C4 WRC)

Citroën locked out the podium in another dominant asphalt performance.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën C4 WRC: Near-perfect asphalt handling made it unbeatable in Germany.
  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Competitive in dry conditions but less effective in mixed grip situations.

Cars needed braking stability and agility for tight vineyard hairpins.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Grip Changes: Pacenotes flagged wet patches and surface transitions.
  • Hinkelsteins: Avoiding these concrete blocks was critical to finishing.
  • Mixed Conditions: Weather forecasts had to be integrated into tire strategy.

Germany rewarded precision braking, smooth lines, and adaptable tire strategies.

title: 2010 Rally Japan (Japan) — WRC Rd.10
bio: Based in Sapporo on Hokkaido island, Rally Japan offered tight, technical gravel stages. Sébastien Ogier capitalized on Loeb’s rare off-form performance to secure his second career win.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rally Japan

Date: September 9–12, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Sapporo, Hokkaido

Total Distance: 1,272.04 km overall (303.54 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 53 starters, 46 finishers

Japan’s compact gravel tests were tight and twisty, rewarding rhythm over outright speed. Ogier outpaced Latvala to take a controlled victory while Loeb finished out of podium contention.

🗺️ Route Details

Stages wound through forests near Sapporo, with a mix of slow corners and short straights.

  • Rikubetsu & Sikot: Narrow gravel tracks lined by trees.
  • Jump Sections: Short crests requiring precise speed control.
  • Sapporo Dome SSS: Indoor stage with mixed-surface spectacle.

Soft gravel often degraded quickly, creating deep ruts for later runners.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën C4 WRC)

2nd Place: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Focus RS WRC 09)

3rd Place: Petter Solberg & Chris Patterson (Citroën C4 WRC)

Ogier’s second WRC win confirmed his growing reputation as a future champion.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën C4 WRC: Agile on narrow roads with excellent grip in loose gravel.
  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Durable and stable in rougher sections.

Cars with compliant suspension and strong low-speed traction excelled here.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Tight Corners: Pacenotes had to be extremely precise for short braking zones.
  • Rutting: Co-drivers flagged deeper ruts that could unsettle the car.
  • Indoor Stage Adjustments: Rapid setup changes for Sapporo Dome’s surface mix.

Japan rewarded measured aggression, car preservation, and error-free pacenotes.

title: 2010 Rallye de France — Alsace (France) — WRC Rd.11
bio: Moved from Corsica to Sébastien Loeb’s home region of Alsace, Rallye de France became a celebration for the new seven-time champion as he clinched the 2010 title with a dominant victory.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rallye de France — Alsace

Date: September 30 – October 3, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Strasbourg, France

Total Distance: 1,272.31 km overall (351.06 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 67 starters, 59 finishers

Relocated to Loeb’s home region, the Alsace event drew massive local crowds. Loeb responded with a commanding drive to secure his seventh consecutive WRC title on home soil.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally’s all-asphalt stages passed through vineyards, forests, and narrow village roads.

  • Vineyard Lanes: Technical, narrow tarmac requiring precise car placement.
  • Forest Roads: Faster, shaded sections with variable grip.
  • Urban Stage: Strasbourg’s city streets for the ceremonial start and finish.

Weather shifts between sunny and damp created challenging tire calls.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

2nd Place: Dani Sordo & Marc Martí (Citroën C4 WRC)

3rd Place: Petter Solberg & Chris Patterson (Citroën C4 WRC)

Loeb’s win sealed his 2010 title in front of his hometown fans.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën C4 WRC: Dominant on asphalt, with perfect balance in tight corners.
  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Consistent but unable to match Citroën’s pace on tarmac.

Asphalt tuning emphasized precision steering and braking stability.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Grip Variability: Co-drivers highlighted damp patches and mud dragged from cuts.
  • Village Sections: Narrow roads required millimeter-accurate calls.
  • Public Crowds: Intense atmosphere demanded driver focus despite distractions.

Alsace rewarded discipline, local knowledge, and flawless tarmac execution.

title: 2010 Rally de España (Spain) — WRC Rd.12
bio: Spain’s mixed-surface format returned, starting on gravel before switching to asphalt. Sébastien Loeb adapted best, dominating both terrains to secure another victory.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rally de España

Date: October 22–24, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Salou, Catalonia

Total Distance: 1,302.13 km overall (344.88 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 59 starters, 48 finishers

The rally’s unique format opened with gravel on day one before switching to smooth asphalt for the remaining legs. Loeb’s adaptability was unmatched as he pulled clear of the field.

🗺️ Route Details

Stages were centered in the Tarragona region, with coastal views and a mix of surfaces.

  • Gravel Opening: Loose, dusty roads with sweeping bends.
  • Asphalt Transition: Circuit-like tarmac for days two and three.
  • Coastal Loops: Scenic but exposed to gusting winds.

Teams had to make major setup changes between Friday and Saturday for the surface switch.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

2nd Place: Petter Solberg & Chris Patterson (Citroën C4 WRC)

3rd Place: Dani Sordo & Marc Martí (Citroën C4 WRC)

A Citroën 1–2–3 locked out the podium in Spain’s mixed-surface challenge.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën C4 WRC: Equally strong on gravel and tarmac after setup change.
  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Competitive on gravel but slightly slower on smooth asphalt.

Cars needed dual-surface versatility and efficient service conversions.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Surface Swap: Co-drivers adjusted pacenote style for different braking points and grip levels.
  • Wind Gusts: Required steering corrections in coastal sections.
  • Dust & Gravel Cuts: Loose surface on day one reduced visibility and traction.

Spain rewarded adaptability and precise preparation for its mixed-terrain nature.

title: 2010 Wales Rally GB (United Kingdom) — WRC Rd.13
bio: The season finale in Wales brought muddy forest tracks and foggy mornings. Jari-Matti Latvala mastered the treacherous grip to take his second win of the year.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Wales Rally GB

Date: November 11–14, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Cardiff, Wales

Total Distance: 1,513.03 km overall (348.22 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 65 starters, 54 finishers

Typical autumn weather brought heavy rain, deep mud, and persistent mist across Welsh forests. Latvala kept a clean run while rivals faltered to end the season with a win for Ford.

🗺️ Route Details

Classic stages in south and mid-Wales offered slick gravel and narrow lines.

  • Rhondda & Myherin: Fast but muddy with hidden ruts.
  • Halfway & Sweet Lamb: Mixed technical sections and open hillside sprints.
  • Night Stages: Low visibility compounded by rain and fog.

The rally tested endurance with long liaisons between service halts.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Focus RS WRC 09)

2nd Place: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën C4 WRC)

3rd Place: Petter Solberg & Chris Patterson (Citroën C4 WRC)

Latvala’s measured drive contrasted with others’ mistakes, sealing Ford’s year on a high note.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Focus RS WRC 09: Stable in slippery conditions and forgiving on rougher cuts.
  • Citroën C4 WRC: Quick but occasionally hampered by traction loss in heavy mud.

Mud-clearing bodywork and effective differentials were key to pace in Wales.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Fog & Rain: Co-drivers relied on split-second calls to keep speed without over-committing.
  • Mud Buildup: Affected braking distances and grip through long corners.
  • Variable Grip: Constantly changing traction made risk management crucial.

Wales rewarded patience, smooth driving, and unwavering trust in pacenotes.

title: 2010 Rallye Sanremo (Italy) — IRC Rd.10
bio: The iconic asphalt round of the Intercontinental Rally Challenge featured twisty mountain passes above the Ligurian coast. Paolo Andreucci thrilled home fans with a measured victory for Peugeot.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2010 Rallye Sanremo

Date: September 23–25, 2010

Start/Finish Location: Sanremo, Italy

Total Distance: 491.84 km overall (220.03 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 56 starters, 39 finishers

Twisty Ligurian tarmac with long climbs and descents defined this IRC classic. Andreucci held off Juho Hänninen and Kris Meeke to take a celebrated home win.

🗺️ Route Details

Stages in the Maritime Alps offered narrow switchbacks and variable grip.

  • Night Leg: Traditional evening stages added drama and tire wear complexity.
  • Colle d’Oggia & Colle Langan: Signature mountain passes with tight hairpins.
  • Urban Super Special: Short, high-energy loop through Sanremo streets.

Weather changes at altitude often split tire strategies in the field.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Paolo Andreucci & Anna Andreussi (Peugeot 207 S2000)

2nd Place: Juho Hänninen & Mikko Markkula (Škoda Fabia S2000)

3rd Place: Kris Meeke & Paul Nagle (Peugeot 207 S2000)

Peugeot and Škoda traded stage wins, but Andreucci’s pace on Colle Langan was decisive.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 207 S2000: Strong uphill acceleration and nimble in tight hairpins.
  • Škoda Fabia S2000: Balanced and reliable, keeping pressure until the final loop.

Asphalt cars needed precise suspension geometry for both mountain climbs and urban sprints.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Switchback Sequences: Co-drivers kept a rapid rhythm for back-to-back hairpins.
  • Altitude Weather Shifts: Calls adjusted for grip changes with rain and shade.
  • Night Visibility: Light pod aiming was critical for the evening leg.

Sanremo rewarded smooth, patient driving and precise pacenote execution under pressure.

title: 2011 Dakar Rally (Argentina–Chile)
bio: The third South American Dakar saw Volkswagen continue its dominance in the car category, with Nasser Al-Attiyah finally taking the top spot ahead of Giniel de Villiers and Carlos Sainz.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Dakar Rally (33rd running)

Date: January 1–16, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Buenos Aires, Argentina (looping through Argentina & Chile)

Total Distance: Approximately 9,500 km (≈5,000 km of timed special stages)

Participating Teams: 407 vehicles across categories (170 bikes/quads, 140 cars, 67 trucks)

Nasser Al-Attiyah, after years of near-misses, claimed his first Dakar victory, leading a Volkswagen 1–3. Stages across the Andes and Atacama tested navigation, endurance, and mechanical resilience in punishing summer heat.

🗺️ Route Details

A demanding trans-Andean loop from Buenos Aires, over the Andes into Chile, and back again.

  • Atacama Desert: Deep dunes and soft fesh-fesh sand near Copiapó and Iquique.
  • Andean Passes: High-altitude crossings affecting engine performance and crew stamina.
  • Argentine Pampas: Fast, open pistes requiring careful navigation.

Mid-event marathon stages required teams to manage without full service assistance.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner (Cars): Nasser Al-Attiyah & Timo Gottschalk (Volkswagen Race Touareg 3)

2nd Place (Cars): Giniel de Villiers & Dirk von Zitzewitz (Volkswagen Race Touareg 3)

3rd Place (Cars): Carlos Sainz & Lucas Cruz (Volkswagen Race Touareg 3)

Al-Attiyah’s measured approach minimized mistakes and mechanical strain, delivering a well-earned victory.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Volkswagen Race Touareg 3: Proven durability, improved suspension travel, and strong turbo-diesel torque.
  • BMW X3 CC: Stage-winning potential but more fragile under sustained dune conditions.

Cooling efficiency and suspension reliability were paramount in the 2011 edition.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Dune Navigation: Demanded accurate compass bearings and reading of sand formations.
  • Altitude Effects: Reduced engine output and crew fatigue at over 4,000 m.
  • Mechanical Fatigue: Continuous rough terrain tested every component over two weeks.

The 2011 Dakar rewarded patience, consistency, and teamwork as much as outright pace.

title: 2011 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo (Monaco/France) — IRC
bio: The centenary edition of Monte Carlo saw icy asphalt and snow-covered cols return in force. Bryan Bouffier’s inspired tire calls propelled him to a stunning upset victory.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Rallye Automobile Monte-Carlo (100th Anniversary)

Date: January 19–22, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Valence → Monaco

Total Distance: 1,341 km overall (337.06 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 121 starters, 60 finishers

This milestone edition was marked by heavy snow on key stages, making tire strategy critical. Bryan Bouffier made a bold studded-tire gamble on day two that vaulted him into the lead, which he never relinquished.

🗺️ Route Details

The route featured legendary Alpine cols and mixed-surface conditions.

  • Col de Turini: Snow-lined hairpins and slippery descents.
  • Col de l’Echarasson: Icy midsections demanding precision braking.
  • Night Stages: Added complexity to tire temperature management.

Frequent microclimate shifts made weather notes as important as pacenotes.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Bryan Bouffier & Xavier Panseri (Peugeot 207 S2000)

2nd Place: Freddy Loix & Frédéric Miclotte (Škoda Fabia S2000)

3rd Place: Guy Wilks & Phil Pugh (Peugeot 207 S2000)

Bouffier’s win was a masterclass in tire selection under changing conditions.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 207 S2000: Excellent traction and balance on mixed-surface Alpine tarmac.
  • Škoda Fabia S2000: Consistent pace across all weather conditions.

Stud patterns and compound flexibility were decisive for outright performance.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Microclimates: Co-drivers tracked evolving snow/ice coverage between passes.
  • Grip Variability: Sudden changes mid-corner demanded adaptable driving.
  • Night Visibility: Proper lighting setup was critical on icy descents.

Monte’s centenary proved that strategy could outweigh outright speed in winter rallying.

title: 2011 Rally Sweden (Sweden) — WRC Rd.1
bio: The only full-snow event on the calendar saw a fierce duel between Mikko Hirvonen, Mads Østberg, and Jari-Matti Latvala. Hirvonen emerged on top, securing his second Swedish win.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Rally Sweden

Date: February 10–13, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Total Distance: 1,961.29 km overall (351.00 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 59 starters, 49 finishers

With a fresh layer of snow and firm ice beneath, Rally Sweden delivered classic high-speed winter rallying. Hirvonen fought off a surprise challenge from Østberg to claim victory by under seven seconds.

🗺️ Route Details

The route featured sweeping forest roads, narrow ice-covered stretches, and cross-border stages in Norway.

  • Vargåsen: Featuring the iconic Colin’s Crest jump.
  • Likenäs: Long, flowing stages with consistent ice grip.
  • Karlstad Super Special: Short opening/closing stage for spectators.

Stud management was crucial to maintaining grip and stability on the second pass.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Mikko Hirvonen & Jarmo Lehtinen (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

2nd Place: Mads Østberg & Jonas Andersson (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

3rd Place: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

Ford swept the podium with the debuting Fiesta RS WRC proving instantly competitive.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Fiesta RS WRC: Nimble, stable, and quick on ice with effective stud retention.
  • Citröen DS3 WRC: Strong debut pace but not enough to break Ford’s winter advantage.

Suspension compliance and weight transfer control were key for stability on snowbanks.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Snowbanks: Drivers used them to aid rotation but risked time loss if stuck.
  • Cold Temperatures: Required mechanical warm-up routines before pushing.
  • Jump Landings: Pacenotes had to anticipate landing grip on icy surfaces.

Sweden in 2011 was a true test of winter rally mastery, rewarding precision and bravery.

title: 2011 Rally México (Mexico) — WRC Rd.2
bio: The first gravel rally of the 2011 WRC season brought high-altitude heat and long mountain stages. Sébastien Loeb mastered the conditions to claim his fifth consecutive Mexican victory.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Rally México

Date: March 3–6, 2011

Start/Finish Location: León, Guanajuato

Total Distance: 1,022.30 km overall (364.87 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 24 starters, 18 finishers

Thin mountain air cut engine performance by up to 30%, while daytime temperatures soared. Loeb’s strategic tire use and minimal mistakes earned him a commanding win over Mikko Hirvonen.

🗺️ Route Details

Stages wound through the Sierra de Lobos and Sierra de Guanajuato mountains.

  • Ibarrilla: Rocky climbs and tight descents.
  • Otates: Longest stage of the rally, mixing fast and slow gravel.
  • Guanajuato Street Stage: Ceremonial opener through tunnels and plazas.

High altitudes demanded careful engine mapping and cooling strategies.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën DS3 WRC)

2nd Place: Mikko Hirvonen & Jarmo Lehtinen (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

3rd Place: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

Loeb’s consistency underlined Citroën’s strength on rough gravel in 2011.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën DS3 WRC: Balanced and responsive despite thin-air power loss.
  • Ford Fiesta RS WRC: Stable but slightly less explosive on climbs.

Puncture protection and cooling efficiency were decisive factors.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Altitude Effects: Pacenotes adjusted braking points for reduced engine braking.
  • Loose Gravel: Second-pass ruts risked damaging suspension.
  • Heat Management: Tire preservation was critical during long loops.

Mexico rewarded smooth driving and mechanical sympathy in punishing conditions.

title: 2011 Rally de Portugal (Portugal) — WRC Rd.3
bio: Fast, flowing gravel in the Algarve saw Sébastien Ogier take a statement victory over Loeb and Latvala, signaling a shift in Citroën’s team dynamics.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Rally de Portugal

Date: March 24–27, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Faro, Algarve

Total Distance: 1,344.15 km overall (385.37 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 37 starters, 31 finishers

Portugal’s southern stages offered a mix of high-speed sections and technical climbs. Ogier controlled the rally from the front, earning his third career WRC win and first of the season.

🗺️ Route Details

Gravel roads across the Algarve featured medium grip and sweeping lines.

  • Santa Clara & Almodôvar: Long, technical stages with elevation changes.
  • Loulé: Coastal wind exposure affecting braking points.
  • Lisbon Super Special: Ceremonial urban tarmac stage.

Dust clouds made visibility a factor for following crews.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën DS3 WRC)

2nd Place: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën DS3 WRC)

3rd Place: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

Ogier’s pace and clean execution put Loeb under rare intra-team pressure.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën DS3 WRC: Agile and responsive in tight gravel corners.
  • Ford Fiesta RS WRC: Stable at speed but slightly slower in acceleration zones.

Suspension setups balanced comfort over rough sections with grip in fast sweepers.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Dust Management: Pacenotes accounted for reduced visibility.
  • Mixed Grip: Corner entries varied from loose to compact gravel.
  • Heat & Wear: Tire choices influenced by afternoon stage temperatures.

Portugal rewarded assertive but controlled driving to stay ahead of road evolution.

title: 2011 Jordan Rally (Jordan) — WRC Rd.4
bio: With the opening day canceled due to shipping delays, the Jordan Rally became the shortest WRC event in history. Sébastien Ogier edged Jari-Matti Latvala by just 0.2 seconds — the closest finish ever in WRC.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Jordan Rally

Date: April 14–16, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Dead Sea, Jordan

Total Distance: 659.54 km overall (333.04 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 31 starters, 28 finishers

A logistical hiccup cut the rally to two days, but the racing remained intense. Ogier and Latvala traded seconds until the Frenchman won by the smallest margin in WRC history.

🗺️ Route Details

Stages along the Dead Sea were fast but narrow, with loose gravel on the edges.

  • Jordan Valley: Long straights broken by tight hairpins.
  • Desert Plains: Wide-open sections exposed to crosswinds.
  • Heat: High ambient temps tested tire and cooling performance.

The compact schedule heightened pressure on crews with no room for recovery drives.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën DS3 WRC)

2nd Place: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

3rd Place: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën DS3 WRC)

The 0.2s margin remains unmatched as the tightest WRC finish ever recorded.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën DS3 WRC: Superior on braking stability and tight corner exits.
  • Ford Fiesta RS WRC: Strong traction in loose gravel sections.

Minimal time for adjustments meant cars had to be quick out of the box.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Compressed Schedule: No margin for error — one mistake could end victory hopes.
  • Loose Edges: Pacenotes flagged off-line hazards in narrow sections.
  • Heat Fatigue: Crew hydration crucial in 30°C+ conditions.

Jordan in 2011 proved that even a shortened rally could deliver historic drama.

title: 2011 Rally d’Italia Sardegna (Italy) — WRC Rd.5
bio: Sardinia’s narrow, rocky gravel returned to the calendar, punishing mistakes and mechanical fragility. Sébastien Loeb took a measured victory over Mikko Hirvonen in rough Mediterranean heat.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Rally d’Italia Sardegna

Date: May 5–8, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Olbia, Sardinia

Total Distance: 1,183.12 km overall (339.70 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 33 starters, 28 finishers

Hot, dusty, and unforgiving, Sardinia demanded precision to avoid punctures and suspension damage. Loeb kept a steady pace to claim another gravel win, while others faltered in the rocky conditions.

🗺️ Route Details

The rally featured narrow, technical gravel tracks winding through hills and coastline.

  • Monte Grighine: Rocky climbs and descents with minimal margin for error.
  • Coastal Loops: Wind and sand patches added unpredictability.
  • Olbia Super Special: Urban night stage for spectators.

Loose gravel on the opening passes meant road position was critical.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën DS3 WRC)

2nd Place: Mikko Hirvonen & Jarmo Lehtinen (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

3rd Place: Petter Solberg & Chris Patterson (Citroën DS3 WRC)

Loeb’s controlled pace allowed him to manage tires and avoid damage in harsh terrain.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën DS3 WRC: Agile in tight sections and resilient to heat stress.
  • Ford Fiesta RS WRC: Strong pace in fast sections but vulnerable to punctures.

Cooling and suspension robustness were decisive factors for Sardinia.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Rock Hazards: Pacenotes marked high-risk corners to avoid punctures.
  • Dust Trails: Required patience in close battles.
  • Heat Management: Crew endurance and brake cooling were key.

Sardinia rewarded patience, precision, and mechanical sympathy.

title: 2011 Rally Argentina (Argentina) — WRC Rd.6
bio: Argentina’s rugged, varied surfaces set the stage for a fierce fight between Sébastien Loeb, Mikko Hirvonen, and Sébastien Ogier. Loeb won after a late charge on the final day.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Rally Argentina

Date: May 26–29, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Villa Carlos Paz, Córdoba

Total Distance: 1,457.08 km overall (378.15 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 33 starters, 30 finishers

The rally offered a mix of soft gravel, rocky mountain tracks, and foggy hill stages. Loeb came from third place after the penultimate day to overtake both Ogier and Hirvonen for the win.

🗺️ Route Details

Stages ranged from wide valley roads to narrow mountain passes.

  • El Condor: Iconic high-altitude stage with fog and narrow hairpins.
  • Mina Clavero: Rocky descents with loose gravel.
  • Valley Sprints: Faster, flowing gravel with big crowds lining the route.

Varied surfaces required flexible setups and rapid adaptation.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën DS3 WRC)

2nd Place: Mikko Hirvonen & Jarmo Lehtinen (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

3rd Place: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën DS3 WRC)

Loeb’s experience and late-stage pace clinched a hard-fought win.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën DS3 WRC: Adaptable to mixed surfaces and strong at altitude.
  • Ford Fiesta RS WRC: Consistent grip in loose gravel and high-speed stability.

Suspension tuning for both soft gravel and rocky sections was vital.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Altitude & Fog: Co-drivers adjusted calls for reduced visibility.
  • Surface Changes: Mixed grip demanded constant pace adjustments.
  • Rock Strikes: Tire preservation played a major role.

Argentina in 2011 rewarded adaptability and strategic pace control.

title: 2011 Acropolis Rally (Greece) — WRC Rd.7
bio: Back on the calendar after a year away, the Acropolis Rally delivered punishing heat, rough gravel, and a tight duel between Sébastien Ogier and Sébastien Loeb. Ogier triumphed with a calculated push on the final day.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Acropolis Rally

Date: June 16–19, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Loutraki, Greece

Total Distance: 1,193.52 km overall (348.80 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 33 starters, 28 finishers

Greece’s return to the WRC brought searing heat, rocky mountain tracks, and car-breaking conditions. Ogier outpaced Loeb in the closing stages to secure victory.

🗺️ Route Details

Stages were primarily rough gravel, winding through mountains and valleys.

  • Loutraki Loops: Fast but rocky with risk of punctures.
  • Mountain Climbs: Long ascents in high heat.
  • Dusty Descents: Low visibility for following cars.

Car preservation was as important as outright speed in the Acropolis’ harsh terrain.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën DS3 WRC)

2nd Place: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën DS3 WRC)

3rd Place: Mikko Hirvonen & Jarmo Lehtinen (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

Ogier’s discipline and tire preservation gave him the edge in brutal Greek heat.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën DS3 WRC: Balanced grip and durability in rough gravel.
  • Ford Fiesta RS WRC: Competitive pace but more susceptible to punctures.

Suspension toughness and heat resistance were essential for finishing strong.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Rock Avoidance: Pacenotes highlighted large embedded stones.
  • Heat Fatigue: Crew hydration and mental stamina were critical.
  • Dust Clouds: Late braking zones adjusted for low visibility.

The Acropolis Rally once again proved why it’s called the Rally of the Gods.

title: 2011 Rally Finland (Finland) — WRC Rd.8
bio: The ‘Grand Prix on Gravel’ saw Sébastien Loeb battle local specialists in a high-speed fight through Finland’s famous jumps and forest roads. Loeb’s measured aggression delivered another win.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Rally Finland

Date: July 28–30, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Jyväskylä, Finland

Total Distance: 1,243.16 km overall (314.39 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 39 starters, 34 finishers

High-speed gravel stages lined with trees and punctuated by massive jumps made Rally Finland a driver favorite. Loeb combined speed with precision to keep local stars like Jari-Matti Latvala at bay.

🗺️ Route Details

Fast, flowing gravel roads through dense forest with iconic jumps.

  • Ouninpohja: The most famous stage in rallying, with enormous flat-out jumps.
  • Jukojärvi: High-speed sweeping corners requiring perfect rhythm.
  • Harju Super Special: Tight city stage for spectators.

Average speeds exceeded 120 km/h, demanding fearless commitment.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën DS3 WRC)

2nd Place: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

3rd Place: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën DS3 WRC)

Loeb became the first non-Nordic driver in years to beat the locals on their home turf through raw pace and consistency.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën DS3 WRC: Stable at high speed with excellent suspension travel.
  • Ford Fiesta RS WRC: Very competitive on jumps and fast gravel.

Shock absorber performance and chassis stability were critical for landing jumps smoothly.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Blind Crests: Pacenote precision for jumps and landings was vital.
  • High Speeds: Small errors could have huge consequences.
  • Consistency: Maintaining top speed while avoiding mistakes decided the rally.

Rally Finland showcased rallying at its fastest and most spectacular.

title: 2011 Rallye Deutschland (Germany) — WRC Rd.9
bio: Germany’s tarmac challenge saw Sébastien Ogier topple Loeb’s long-running dominance on home soil. Tight vineyard roads and military asphalt pushed precision to the limit.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Rallye Deutschland

Date: August 19–21, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Trier, Germany

Total Distance: 1,169.07 km overall (359.59 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 42 starters, 37 finishers

After years of Loeb dominance, Sébastien Ogier finally broke through with a win in Germany. Precision braking and tire choice in changeable weather were decisive factors.

🗺️ Route Details

A mix of narrow vineyard lanes, bumpy military asphalt, and smooth country roads.

  • Mosel Vineyards: Tight hairpins between vines with little runoff.
  • Baumholder Panzerplatte: Wide concrete military roads lined with hinkelsteins.
  • Saarland Stages: Faster tarmac with mixed grip.

Weather shifts forced teams to gamble on tire choices multiple times.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Citroën DS3 WRC)

2nd Place: Sébastien Loeb & Daniel Elena (Citroën DS3 WRC)

3rd Place: Dani Sordo & Carlos del Barrio (Mini John Cooper Works WRC)

Ogier ended Loeb’s unbroken streak of Rallye Deutschland victories since its WRC debut in 2002.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Citroën DS3 WRC: Dominant on tarmac with sharp turn-in and braking stability.
  • Mini JCW WRC: Competitive showing in only its debut season.

Braking precision and tire longevity were deciding factors.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Changing Weather: Rapidly shifting grip levels required real-time pacenote updates.
  • Hinkelstein Barriers: Demanded absolute accuracy on Panzerplatte.
  • Tire Strategy: Calls had to be made with incomplete weather info.

Germany in 2011 proved even the most dominant streaks can end with the right pace and precision.

title: 2011 Rally Australia (Australia) — WRC Rd.10
bio: Coffs Harbour hosted a dramatic Rally Australia filled with rain-soaked gravel and unpredictable grip. Mikko Hirvonen took a critical win in his title fight with Loeb and Ogier.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Rally Australia

Date: September 8–11, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Coffs Harbour, New South Wales

Total Distance: 1,260.90 km overall (368.96 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 30 starters, 25 finishers

Heavy rain turned the fast Australian gravel stages into slippery clay, catching out top drivers including Loeb and Ogier. Hirvonen kept his Ford Fiesta RS WRC upright to take maximum points.

🗺️ Route Details

Fast, flowing gravel stages through forests and farmland with mixed grip.

  • Valla Stages: High-speed forest runs with slippery clay when wet.
  • Welshs Creek: Narrow sections bordered by trees.
  • Super Specials: Short spectator-friendly town stages.

Changing weather made setup choice a gamble.

🏆 Results

Overall Winner: Mikko Hirvonen & Jarmo Lehtinen (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

2nd Place: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Ford Fiesta RS WRC)

3rd Place: Petter Solberg & Chris Patterson (Citroën DS3 WRC)

Ford capitalized on Citroën’s misfortunes to take a dominant 1–2 finish.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Ford Fiesta RS WRC: Stable in slippery gravel and strong in the wet.
  • Citroën DS3 WRC: Quick in the dry but prone to sliding in clay.

Suspension compliance and predictable handling were essential in these conditions.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Wet Clay Grip Loss: Pacenotes had to reflect dramatic grip changes.
  • Visibility: Rain and mud spray reduced sightlines.
  • Survival Pace: Many top drivers retired due to crashes or off-road excursions.

Rally Australia 2011 rewarded those who balanced caution with speed in treacherous weather.

title: 2011 Rallye de France – Alsace (France) — WRC Rd.11
bio: Sébastien Ogier took a dramatic win on home soil in Alsace, capitalizing on Loeb’s mechanical retirement. The victory kept the title fight alive heading into the final rounds.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2011 Rallye de France – Alsace

Date: September 29 – October 2, 2011

Start/Finish Location: Strasbourg, France

Total Distance: 1,272.31 km overall (340.10 km of special stages)

Participating Teams: 39 starters, 33 finishers

Returning for its second year in Alsace, the rally saw huge local support for Loeb — but an engine issue ended his rally early, handing Ogier the win in front of passionate French fans.

🗺️ Route Details

Tarmac stages through vineyards, rolling hills, and Alsatian villages.

  • Vosges Mountains: High-speed tarmac with changing grip.
  • Vineyard Roads: Narrow, technical sections lined with stone walls.
  • City Super Special: Strasbourg-based spectator stage.

Dry and sunny weather made for high grip but demanded precision braking.

Event Name: 2014 Rally Liepāja

Date: January 31 – February 2, 2014

Start/Finish Location: Liepāja, Latvia

Total Distance: Approximately 865 kilometers (240 km competitive)

Participating Teams: 49 crews

One of the fastest winter rallies on the ERC calendar, Rally Liepāja offered wide, snow-covered gravel roads where momentum and confidence in studded tires were crucial for competitive times.

🗺️ Route Details

Key stage areas included:

  • Kuldīga Region: Long straights and sweeping snowy corners.
  • Liepāja Forests: Tight, tree-lined snow tracks requiring precision.
  • High-Speed Sections: Average speeds exceeding 110 km/h on snow.

The frozen gravel base offered surprising grip with studs, but mistakes often resulted in deep snowbank excursions.

🏆 Results

Winner: Esapekka Lappi & Janne Ferm (Škoda Fabia S2000)

2nd Place: Sepp Wiegand & Frank Christian (Škoda Fabia S2000)

3rd Place: Craig Breen & Scott Martin (Peugeot 207 S2000)

Lappi’s flat-out style in the Škoda delivered a dominant win in the frozen Baltic landscapes.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Škoda Fabia S2000: Excellent stability at high speed on snow.
  • Peugeot 207 S2000: Strong traction out of slower snowy corners.
  • Mitsubishi Lancer Evo X: Privateer favorite for its robustness in tough winter rallies.

Top cars combined speed and stability on the frozen surface, with minimal time lost in tight sections.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • High-Speed Commitment: Drivers had to trust pacenotes and carry speed into blind snowy corners.
  • Snowbanks: Useful but unforgiving if clipped at the wrong angle.
  • Visibility: Snow dust could obscure vision when following closely.

Rally Liepāja was a pure speed test in winter conditions, pushing drivers to the edge of control.

title: 2014 Rally Sweden
bio: The WRC’s only full-snow rally offered blistering pace on frozen gravel and rewarded those most skilled at exploiting snowbanks for cornering advantage.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2014 Rally Sweden

Date: February 5–8, 2014

Start Location: Karlstad, Sweden

Finish Location: Hagfors, Sweden

Total Distance: Approximately 1,590 kilometers (322 km competitive)

Participating Teams: 46 crews

Rally Sweden delivered its trademark high-speed stages on compacted snow and ice, with studded tires allowing incredible cornering grip. Precision driving and bravery through sweeping snow-lined bends were essential.

🗺️ Route Details

The route crossed into Norway for some stages:

  • Vargåsen: Home of the famous Colin’s Crest jump.
  • Röjden: A cross-border stage mixing Swedish and Norwegian snow roads.
  • Hagfors Sprint: Tight, technical spectator-friendly stage on snow.

Fast sweeping bends and long straights defined the event, making aerodynamic stability and traction key.

🏆 Results

Winner: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Volkswagen Polo R WRC)

2nd Place: Andreas Mikkelsen & Mikko Markkula (Volkswagen Polo R WRC)

3rd Place: Mads Østberg & Jonas Andersson (Citroën DS3 WRC)

Volkswagen’s 1-2 finish showed their snow mastery, with Latvala’s experience proving decisive.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Volkswagen Polo R WRC: Excellent balance and traction in snow.
  • Citroën DS3 WRC: Agile and quick in technical snow sections.
  • Ford Fiesta RS WRC: Strong privateer weapon in snow rallies.

Studded tire performance and chassis stability separated the fastest from the rest.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Snowbanks: Used for extra cornering grip but risky if hit too hard.
  • Cold Temperatures: Engine reliability and crew comfort were concerns.
  • High Speed: Mistakes at over 150 km/h on snow could end a rally instantly.

Rally Sweden was a showcase of controlled aggression and winter rally mastery.

title: 2014 Rally México
bio: The first gravel event of the 2014 WRC season, Rally México delivered thin mountain air, punishing rocky roads, and soaring jumps in the Guanajuato region.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2014 Rally Guanajuato México

Date: March 6–9, 2014

Start Location: Guanajuato City, Mexico

Finish Location: León, Mexico

Total Distance: Approximately 1,000 kilometers (399 km competitive)

Participating Teams: 27 crews

High-altitude gravel stages tested engine performance and driver stamina. Thin air reduced engine power by up to 30%, forcing teams to focus on momentum and mechanical sympathy over outright aggression.

🗺️ Route Details

Notable stages included:

  • El Chocolate: Long, technical climbs with breathtaking mountain views.
  • Otates: High-speed gravel with sharp rock outcrops.
  • Street Stage Guanajuato: Iconic night opener through underground mining tunnels.

The rally's punishing surface demanded careful tire and brake management, especially during the long Sunday Power Stage.

🏆 Results

Winner: Sébastien Ogier & Julien Ingrassia (Volkswagen Polo R WRC)

2nd Place: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Volkswagen Polo R WRC)

3rd Place: Mads Østberg & Jonas Andersson (Citroën DS3 WRC)

Ogier dominated with pace and consistency, securing back-to-back wins in Mexico.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Volkswagen Polo R WRC: Maintained performance despite altitude losses.
  • Citroën DS3 WRC: Durable under harsh gravel impacts.
  • Ford Fiesta RS WRC: Strong in privateer hands on loose gravel.

Cooling and engine mapping adaptations were critical to surviving Mexico's altitude.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Altitude: Affected both engine power and crew endurance.
  • Loose Gravel: Early road position meant sweeping dust and stones for following cars.
  • Long Stages: Required careful tire management and mechanical preservation.

Rally México remains one of the WRC's most unique and physically demanding gravel tests.

title: 2014 Acropolis Rally (Greece)
bio: Known as one of the roughest rallies in the world, the Acropolis Rally returned as a round of the ERC, offering brutal rock-strewn stages under the Greek sun.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2014 Acropolis Rally

Date: March 28–30, 2014

Start/Finish Location: Loutraki, Greece

Total Distance: Approximately 700 kilometers (230 km competitive)

Participating Teams: 28 crews

The Acropolis Rally lived up to its “Rally of Gods” reputation, with car-breaking terrain and soaring temperatures pushing crews and machinery to the limit.

🗺️ Route Details

Key stages included:

  • Bauxites: Rocky mountain passes with narrow switchbacks.
  • Klenia–Mycenae: Historic backdrop with fast, flowing gravel.
  • Loutraki: Rough, car-breaking roads with high ambient heat.

Puncture prevention and suspension strength were crucial to survival.

🏆 Results

Winner: Craig Breen & Scott Martin (Peugeot 208 T16)

2nd Place: Bryan Bouffier & Xavier Panseri (Citroën DS3 R5)

3rd Place: Kajetan Kajetanowicz & Jarosław Baran (Ford Fiesta R5)

Breen’s pace and mechanical sympathy paid off in one of the toughest rallies of the season.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Peugeot 208 T16: Debut win showcasing durability and speed.
  • Citroën DS3 R5: Balanced handling with reliable drivetrain.
  • Ford Fiesta R5: Robust under extreme gravel abuse.

Cars with reinforced suspension and cooling systems thrived on Greek gravel.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Rocks and Ruts: Constant hazard for tires and suspension.
  • Heat: Engine cooling and driver hydration were critical.
  • Dust: Reduced visibility and increased mechanical wear.

The Acropolis Rally punished mistakes and rewarded calculated aggression.

title: 2014 Rally Islas Canarias (Spain)

The Canary Islands rewarded smooth, flowing driving and punished late braking errors.

title: 2014 Rally de Portugal

Portugal’s mix of speed and technicality makes it one of the most respected rallies on the WRC calendar.

title: 2014 SATA Rallye Açores

The Azores remains one of the most visually stunning and technically demanding rallies in Europe.

title: 2014 Rally Argentina
bio: One of the most popular rallies on the calendar, Argentina is known for its passionate fans, rough roads, and iconic water splashes.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Start/Finish Location: Villa Carlos Paz, Argentina

Argentina’s gravel stages mix sandy roads with rocky mountain climbs, delivering one of the most punishing events of the WRC season.

🗺️ Route Details

  • El Condor: Narrow, rocky climb at high altitude.
  • Mina Clavero–Giulio Cesare: Technical and twisty with loose rocks.
  • Santa Rosa: Fast and sandy, with huge water splashes.

Car preservation was as important as outright speed in Argentina’s harsh conditions.

Winner: Jari-Matti Latvala & Miikka Anttila (Volkswagen Polo R WRC)

Latvala’s victory ended Ogier’s winning streak and proved VW’s dominance on gravel.

  • Variable Gravel: From sandy flats to rocky climbs.

  • Altitude: Reduced engine performance in high stages.

Argentina’s combination of fan passion and challenging terrain makes it a season highlight.

title: 2014 Rally d’Italia Sardegna
bio: Rally d’Italia Sardegna is one of the most technical gravel events in Europe, demanding precision on narrow, rocky tracks surrounded by Mediterranean scenery.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

This Mediterranean island rally is known for its narrow gravel roads, high ambient temperatures, and punishing rocky sections that test both driver and machine.

Sardinia remains a rally of precision, survival, and speed management.

title: 2014 Ypres Rally
bio: One of Europe’s most famous asphalt rallies, the Ypres Rally features narrow farm roads, deep ditches, and a passionate Belgian fan base.
details_html:
🏁 Overview

Event Name: 2014 Geko Ypres Rally

Date: June 19–21, 2014

Start/Finish Location: Ypres, Belgium

Total Distance: 643 km (298 km competitive)

Participating Teams: 70 crews

A high-speed tarmac event with tight junctions and unpredictable grip, Ypres requires inch-perfect driving and precise pacenotes.

🗺️ Route Details

  • Langemark: Flat, open farmland roads with sudden 90-degree bends.
  • Dikkebus: Narrow lanes bordered by deep drainage ditches.
  • Hollebeke: Fast asphalt with mixed surface patches.

Cutting corners carried the risk of punctures from hidden rocks in the grass.

Winner: Freddy Loix & Johan Gitsels (Škoda Fabia S2000)

2nd Place: Bryan Bouffier & Xavier Panseri (Citroën DS3 R5)

Loix extended his dominance at Ypres with another controlled victory.

  • Škoda Fabia S2000: Excellent stability and braking performance.

  • Deep Ditches: Severe penalty for overshooting corners.
  • Variable Grip: Mud dragged onto the road by cutting.
  • Tight Junctions: Demanding on braking and steering precision.

Ypres remains a proving ground for asphalt rally specialists.

title: 2014 Rally Poland
bio: A lightning-fast gravel rally, Rally Poland is known for long straights, wide corners, and massive fan turnout along the roadside.

🏁 Overview

With speeds rivaling Rally Finland, Rally Poland is one of the fastest events on the WRC calendar, featuring wide gravel roads and sweeping bends.

  • Goldap: High-speed straights with light gravel covering hard-packed base.

Poland’s rally is a fan favorite and a test of pure speed.

title: 2014 Rally Finland
bio: Rally Finland, nicknamed the 'Grand Prix on Gravel,' is the fastest rally on the WRC calendar, featuring massive jumps, flat-out corners, and blistering average speeds.

🏁 Overview

Known for its flat-out gravel stages and iconic jumps like Ouninpohja, Rally Finland demands bravery, absolute commitment, and perfect pacenotes.

Rally Finland remains the ultimate test of courage and precision in the WRC.

title: 2014 Rallye Deutschland

title: 2014 Rally Australia

title: 2014 Rally Catalunya
bio: Rally Catalunya is the WRC’s only true mixed-surface event, starting on gravel before switching to high-speed asphalt for the final stages.
details_html:

title: 2015 Dakar Rally (Argentina, Bolivia, Chile)

The Dakar continued its reign as the toughest rally raid in the world, with punishing stages across the Andes, the Atacama Desert, and salt flats in Bolivia. Competitors faced mechanical attrition, navigational traps, and extreme weather shifts.

  • Andes Crossing: Stages at altitudes over 4,000 meters, sapping engine performance and driver stamina.
  • Atacama Desert: Endless dunes with soft sand and hidden drop-offs.

The combination of terrain extremes made this edition one of the most unpredictable in years.

Cars Winner: Nasser Al-Attiyah & Mathieu Baumel (Mini All4 Racing)

2nd Place: Giniel de Villiers & Dirk von Zitzewitz (Toyota Hilux)

Al-Attiyah dominated with consistent pace, controlling the rally from the early stages.

🚗 Vehicle Highlights

  • Mini All4 Racing: Proven durability and torque for dune climbing.
  • Toyota Hilux: Reliable in rough terrain with strong suspension travel.

Vehicles had to balance outright speed with rugged reliability to survive the Dakar’s demands.

🧭 Navigation and Challenges

  • Extreme Altitude: Reduced oxygen levels affecting crews and engines.
  • Heat and Cold Swings: From freezing mornings to 40°C afternoons.
  • Navigation Traps: Multiple competitors lost hours searching for waypoints.

The Dakar 2015 was a lesson in patience, adaptability, and survival — both for machines and the humans piloting them.

title: 2015 Jännerrallye (Austria)

title: 2015 Rallye Monte-Carlo (Monaco/France)

title: 2015 Rally Liepāja (Latvia)

The frozen gravel roads along Latvia’s coast created a spectacle of high-speed drifts, rooster tails of snow, and incredible displays of car control.

  • Frozen Gravel: High grip from studded tires, but punishing on mistakes.

The rally rewarded precision at extreme speed, with minimal margin for error.

Rally Mexico was a true survival test, rewarding careful pacing and mechanical sympathy.

title: 2016 Rally Australia (WRC)

title: 2017 Dakar Rally (Paraguay/Bolivia/Argentina)

title: 2017 Rallye Monte-Carlo (WRC)

title: 2017 Rally Sweden (WRC)

title: 2017 Rally Guanajuato México (WRC)
